key_points: The Colonial Pipeline hack in May, caused by Russian-based hackers, led to a gas shortage, increased fuel prices, and a $5 million ransom.
Air Force Secretary Frank Kendall highlighted the vulnerability of US military logistics to cyber attacks at the National Defense Transportation Association conference.
Kendall and Air Force Gen. Jacqueline Van Ovost emphasized the growing threat of cyber attacks and the need for improved cybersecurity within the military's logistics and supply chain.
The Department of Defense heavily depends on commercial vendors for essential commodities, making it vulnerable to disruptions.
Kendall stressed the potential devastation of cyber or kinetic attacks on military networks and infrastructure.
Kendall advocated for more funding to mitigate logistics vulnerabilities, including the need for weapon storage and hardened fuel storage infrastructure.
The Pentagon needs to recruit talented employees and acquire more resilient transportation systems to counter cyber and kinetic attacks.
Nickolas Guertin, nominee for the director of operational test and evaluation (DOT&E), emphasized the need for more resources and automation for cybersecurity testing.
The DOT&E office, responsible for military technology cybersecurity standards, faces challenges due to resource limitations and high demand.
Guertin recommended independent security assessments of cloud services purchased by the Defense Department from commercial vendors.
spokespersons: Air Force Gen. Jacqueline Van Ovost (Head of US Transportation Command)
Nickolas Guertin (Nominee, Director of Operational Test and Evaluation)
